title: Ice Mage
data:
The **Ice Mage** is a [role](/wiki/Role "Role") specific to *[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM")*. It is similar to the [Flame Mage](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage"), except with a focus on ice magic instead of fire magic. Ice Mages start with a [winter wolf cub](/wiki/Winter_wolf_cub "Winter wolf cub") as a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet"). They can be a [doppelganger](/wiki/Doppelganger_\(starting_race\) "Doppelganger (starting race)"), [drow](/wiki/Drow "Drow"), [elf](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)"), [gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)"), [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit_\(starting_race\) "Hobbit (starting race)"), [human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"), [orc](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") or [vampire](/wiki/Vampire_\(starting_race\) "Vampire (starting race)"). According to the guidebook:

Ice Mages command the forces of cold. An experienced Mage can summon great blizzards yet remain unaffected by the turmoil of the elements.

## Starting inventory

- a blessed +1 [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")
- an uncursed +0 [studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor")
- 2-3 uncursed [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration")
- a scroll
- a potion
- a ring
- a [wand of cold](/wiki/Wand_of_cold "Wand of cold")
- three spellbooks: [freezing sphere](/wiki/Freezing_sphere "Freezing sphere"), [cone of cold](/wiki/Cone_of_cold "Cone of cold"), one other enchantment ([slow monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_slow_monster "Spellbook of slow monster") or [confuse monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_confuse_monster "Spellbook of confuse monster"))

An Ice Mage has some [food](/wiki/Food "Food") and - like a [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") - a [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff"). However, a Wizard starts with more random magic items, while an Ice Mage always has a spellbook of freezing sphere and a spellbook of cone of cold.

## Intrisics

- XL 1 : [Cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance")
- XL 7 : Polymorph into baby [white dragon](/wiki/White_dragon "White dragon") form
- XL 13: [Fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance")
- XL 14: Polymorph into adult [white dragon](/wiki/White_dragon "White dragon") form

## Techniques

- XL 1 : [Reinforce memory](/wiki/Reinforce_memory "Reinforce memory") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique")
- XL 5 : [Draw energy](/wiki/Draw_energy "Draw energy") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique")
- XL 10: [Sigil of tempest](/wiki/Sigil_of_tempest "Sigil of tempest") technique
- XL 12: [Power surge](/wiki/Power_surge "Power surge") technique
- XL 20: [Sigil of discharge](/wiki/Sigil_of_discharge "Sigil of discharge") technique

## Quest

- *Main article: [Ice mage quest](/wiki/Ice_mage_quest "Ice mage quest")*

The [Ice Mage]() quest sees you fighting the [Earth Mage](/wiki/Earth_Mage "Earth Mage") for [The Storm Whistle](/wiki/The_Storm_Whistle "The Storm Whistle").

## Gods

- *Main article: [religion](/wiki/Religion "Religion")*

* Lawful: Air
* Neutral: Frost
* Chaotic: Smoke

## Rank titles

The [status line](/wiki/Status_line "Status line") shows you to be one of the following ranks when you reach the specified experience level:

- XL 1-2: Cooler
- XL 3-5: Condenser
- XL 6-9: Chiller
- XL 10-13: Froster
- XL 14-17: Permafroster
- XL 18-21: Icer
- XL 22-25: Freezer
- XL 26-29: Sublimer
- XL 30: Ice-Master

## Strategy

### Choosing a race

Since Ice Mages, like all primary magic-users, start with weak armor and have a difficult time finding suitable upgrades, high dexterity and constitution to keep AC low and HP high are a must. For this reason, hobbits make excellent lawful or neutral Ice Mages — though their max [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") of 16 will hold them back later on. Remember to use the hobbit's blink technique when you see a problem coming up.

### The Early Game: The Sphere

Compared with [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") and [Necromancers](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer"), Ice and Flame Mages are at a special disadvantage in the early game because they cannot directly attack with magic. Whereas other magic-users starting with Attack spells can directly and in one turn damage monsters around them, Ice Mages have to rely on their starting Freeze Sphere spell (in the Matter category) to indirectly damage foes. Freeze Spheres will not necessarily explode immediately when they approach a monster, and may wander around in circles before finding their target.

On the other hand, Freeze Spheres will not expire and will never become hostile if left alone on a level (though they may turn neutral). The only risk in accumulating a small army of spheres to overwhelm any difficult enemies that leap out at you by surprise is that they are just as likely to explode and aggravate friendly or neutral monsters (though not other tame creatures). Freeze and Flame Spheres are a special category of pet that transfer experience and responsibility for kills to the summoner, meaning that a shopkeeper that will remain indifferent to you while your Deva pummels him or her will whip out the shotgun as soon as they get touched by a sphere. Ice Mages should leave early mimics in shops to their wolf cub. Spheres are liable to drift across the shop to the owner just as often as they find their mark. On the other hand, chaotic Ice Mages with mana to spare can let their spheres wander around the corner into an open shop door to slowly blast a shopkeeper to pieces (keep escape items handy if you're trying this). And spheres are perfect for crossing the gap between you and a cross-aligned unicorn.

In the early game, Ice Mages should focus first on bringing their Matter spells to skilled level by casting as many Freeze Sphere spells as possible, starting with the very first turn. Calling up a Freeze Sphere to destroy a goblin is never a waste. The reason for this is that the "Cone of Cold" spell will become much easier to cast as soon as the first skill enhancement is made, allowing the Ice Mage to finally use a direct attack spell. In the meantime, Ice Mages should scrounge around for new armor and improvements to their quarterstaff. Ice Mages should also spend some time strengthening their winter wolf cub, which will turn into a full-grown winter wolf with an appetite for aligned priests when it reaches enough kills. Letting the cub protect you not only against tough, very early monsters like large mimics and rothes, but having them gobble up grid bugs and lichens is a great way to tick up its MaxHP.

### Ice Mage vs. Flame Mage

Ice Mages are also at a special disadvantage compared to [Flame Mages](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage") in the early game: difficult undead such as [human zombies](/wiki/Human_zombie "Human zombie") and [human mummies](/wiki/Human_mummies "Human mummies") are immune to cold-based magic. However, Ice Mages gain an advantage later on when fighting fire-resistant demons, primarily in Gehennom. Additionally, cold magic only risks destroying potions, where fire-based magic will destroy both potions and scrolls.

Ice Mage enchantment magic is less useful than Flame Mage divination magic, which eventually helps cast the [spell of identify](/wiki/Spell_of_identify "Spell of identify"). Also, [fireball](/wiki/Fireball "Fireball") is a more powerful — though less focused — spell than [cone of cold](/wiki/Cone_of_cold "Cone of cold"), which travels in a straight line and can freeze water. Finally, and most importantly in the early game, the Ice Mage's wand of cold is much, much less useful for engraving "Elbereth" than the Flame Mage's wand of fire. Not only is it not permanent, it is much more liable to fail even on the first engraving. In fact, using the wand in such a fashion is a complete waste of a wand charge; the same job can simply be done with your fingers.

### Weapons

In general, an Ice Mage should try to raise the dagger skill to expert since their first sacrifice gift, [Deep Freeze](/wiki/Deep_Freeze "Deep Freeze"), is an [athame](/wiki/Athame "Athame") that functions as a "mini"-[Frost Brand](/wiki/Frost_Brand "Frost Brand").

Characters willing to spend a lot of time sacrificing at an altar will eventually get [Fire Brand](/wiki/Fire_Brand "Fire Brand") or [Frost Brand](/wiki/Frost_Brand "Frost Brand"), both of which work very nicely with Ice Mages' aptitude for long swords. An Ice Mage (of any alignment) willing to wish for an artifact should strongly consider wishing for [Serpent's Tongue](/wiki/Serpent%27s_Tongue "Serpent's Tongue"), a chaotic artifact dagger that deals double damage to *all* monsters, in addition to dealing extra damage to non-poison resistant monsters with a chance of instakilling them. Beyond that, there are several considerations depending on each alignment, since an Ice Mage can be of any alignment:

- Lawfuls should always dip for [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur"), since Ice Mages can raise their long sword skill to Skilled. [The Stake of Van Helsing](/wiki/The_Stake_of_Van_Helsing "The Stake of Van Helsing") is also worth considering for its excellent damage output and slotless [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), but be sure you can survive its [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast")!
- Neutral characters might consider wishing for [The Staff of Aesculapius](/wiki/The_Staff_of_Aesculapius "The Staff of Aesculapius"), since Ice Mages can raise quarterstaves to Skilled, and its double damage and healing against non-drain resistant monsters can prove very powerful. As with the Stake of Van Helsing, be sure you can survive the blast - note that the Staff in particular will blast you if you [invoke](/wiki/Invoke "Invoke") it to heal yourself, considerably diminishing the usefulness of that power.
- Chaotic characters will often have great luck sacrificing at altars for weapons, unlike in vanilla. In addition to being able to get the above-mentioned Serpent's Tongue through sacrifice rather than a wish, they may also receive other super-powerful artifacts such as [Doomblade](/wiki/Doomblade "Doomblade") or the [Bat from Hell](/wiki/Bat_from_Hell "Bat from Hell"), thereby unrestricting the [short sword](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword") and [club](/wiki/Club "Club") skills.

In general, an Ice Mage should try to raise the dagger skill to expert since their first sacrifice gift, [[Deep Freeze]], is an [[athame]] that functions as a "mini"-[[Frost Brand]].

An Ice Mage (of any alignment) willing to wish for an artifact should strongly consider wishing for [[Serpent's Tongue]], a chaotic artifact dagger that deals double damage to ''all'' monsters, in addition to dealing extra damage to non-poison resistant monsters with a chance of instakilling them. Beyond that, there are several considerations depending on each alignment, since an Ice Mage can be of any alignment:

* Lawfuls should always dip for [[Excalibur]], since Ice Mages can raise their long sword skill to Skilled.  [[The Stake of Van Helsing]] is also worth considering for its excellent damage output and slotless [[magic resistance]], but be sure you can survive its [[artifact blast]]!
* Neutral characters might consider wishing for [[The Staff of Aesculapius]], since Ice Mages can raise quarterstaves to Skilled, and its double damage and healing against non-drain resistant monsters can prove very powerful. As with the Stake of Van Helsing, be sure you can survive the blast - note that the Staff in particular will blast you if you [[invoke]] it to heal yourself, considerably diminishing the usefulness of that power.
* Chaotic characters will often have great luck sacrificing at altars for weapons, unlike in vanilla.  In addition to being able to get the above-mentioned Serpent's Tongue through sacrifice rather than a wish, they may also receive other super-powerful artifacts such as [[Doomblade]] or the [[Bat from Hell]], thereby unrestricting the [[short sword]] and [[club]] skills.
